summary: This is an email chain from February 2020 among U.S. Attorney's Office SDNY staff, primarily discussing and approving travel requests for the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The emails detail multiple trips planned for 2019-2020 to conduct victim interviews in Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale, and near Stockholm, Sweden.

connections.description: Both are part of the same investigation team traveling for interviews related to the Epstein case.

events.title: Los Angeles Interview Trip
events.description: Planned travel by the investigation team to Los Angeles for at least one interview on each of three days, with a request for a conference room at the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

events.title: Stockholm, Sweden Interview Trip
events.description: Planned international travel for an interview near Stockholm, Sweden, with instructions to use domestic or domestic-flagged carrier flights.

events.title: Los Angeles Interview Trip
events.description: Travel for an interview or possible interviews in Los Angeles.

events.title: Los Angeles Interview Trip
events.description: Travel for an interview in Los Angeles.

events.title: West Palm Beach Interview Trip
events.description: Travel for an interview in West Palm Beach, with a request to reserve a conference room at a hotel.

events.title: West Palm Beach Meetings and Interviews
events.description: Travel for approximately three days for meetings and interviews with victims in West Palm Beach, Florida.

events.title: Initial Florida Travel Request
events.description: Initial travel request for two days of meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document reveals ongoing investigative activity in the Epstein case (2018R01618) by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York well into 2020, including planned international travel to Sweden.
The investigation involved multiple trips to Los Angeles and Florida (West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale) specifically to conduct victim interviews, often requiring hotel conference rooms.
The email chain shows a standardized process for seeking internal travel approvals, referencing prior trips for the same investigation.
The international trip to Sweden in January 2020 included specific instructions to be mindful of flight carriers and costs, indicating heightened procedural scrutiny.
The case is formally referenced as 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618, an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.'
